recommendations.blurb: More resources curated by Marcus Bullock

recItems.blurb: Reginald "Dwayne" Betts is an incredible writer. This first book, where he describes the experience of going to prison as a teenager, is incredibly accurate. Dwayne was my codefendant and best friend when we committed our crime together, and while we were both sentenced as adults, his experiences of moving through prison did not match mine. He does an incredible job telling his story, all the way up to the day of his release.
recItems.headline: *A Question of Freedom: A Memoir of Learning, Survival, and Coming of Age in Prison*
recItems.label: READ_BOOK

recItems.blurb: Grant's book awakened my senses as an entrepreneur when Flikshop started to gain traction and we became too big of a company to keep bootstrapping. It's hard launching a business when your bank account does not match your vision and drive. Grant's book forced me to think through how I approached growth and tells a more accurate story around the mindset that it takes to achieve real success in business.
recItems.headline: *The 10X Rule: The Only Difference Between Success and Failure*
recItems.label: READ_BOOK

recItems.blurb: Tony Lewis shows the power of love, sacrifice and commitment to service. I remember growing up in Washington, DC during the era that crack cocaine was introduced to my neighborhood and Tony Lewis's father, who was also from DC, made headlines as one of the largest drug kingpins in the country. Tony tells a compelling story and gives the reader an opportunity to see the power of family connections while incarcerated. We created the Flikshop app for families like Tony Lewis's.
recItems.headline: *Slugg: A Boy's Life in the Age of Mass Incarceration*
recItems.label: READ_BOOK
recItems.note:
Tony Lewis Jr. and K.L. Reeves
Independently published, 2017

recItems.blurb: Justice Policy Institute is a national nonprofit that advances conversations and policy around efforts to create a more just criminal justice system. I sit on the board of directors at JPI, and have learned about the power of advocacy during my time there. JPI's research reports also informed me about the reform efforts taking place nationally  around legislation for raising the age for children who are sentenced to prison as adults.
recItems.headline: Justice Policy Institute
recItems.label: EXPLORE

recItems.blurb: This article tells why John Legend invested in Flikshop and why it's important to support founders of color, even if they have committed a crime. There are more than 2.3 million people in prisons in the US, and most of them will come home one day. The Unlocked Futures business accelerator was pivotal for me, and gave us the credibility to begin raising venture capital from other investors.
recItems.headline: "Why John Legend Is Backing Startups Launched By These Former Inmates"
recItems.label: READ_ARTICLE

nodes.whoTheyAre: Marcus Bullock builds tools to help incarcerated people stay connected to their families and communities.
nodes.whyListen:
Following his 2004 release from prison, Marcus Bullock launched a construction business that grew to employ other returning citizens. Bullock is also founder and CEO of Flikshop, Inc., a software company that builds tools to help incarcerated people stay connected to their families and build community. The Flikshop mobile app enables families and nonprofit organizations to send personalized postcards to any person in any cell in the United States, with the mission of using social connections to decrease recidivism. Forbes calls the app "Instagram for prisons."

Bullock also founded the Flikshop School of Business, a program that teaches returning citizens life skills and entrepreneurship via computer coding and software development. He is an inaugural cohort member of Techstars Anywhere 2018 and John Legend’s
Unlocked Futures business accelerators. He is also a member of the Justice Policy Institute's board of directors and serves as an advisor to the Aspen Institute’s Opportunity Youth Incentive Fund.

videoData.description: Over his eight-year prison sentence, Marcus Bullock was sustained by his mother's love -- and by the daily letters and photos she sent of life on the outside. Years later, as an entrepreneur, Bullock asked himself: How can I make it easier for all families to stay connected during incarceration? Enter FlikShop: an app he developed that lets families send quick postcards to loved ones in prison and help keep open a critical line of support.
